analytic.title: Extracting Geometric Models Through Constraint Minimization

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Geometric models that represent the features in a greyscale image allow for alternative visualizations of the features. These alternatives can lead to a greater understanding of the extents and interrelationships of the features in the image. We present a technique that extracts the geometric nature of a feature by constraining a known geometric model to conform to the characteristics of the feature. The constraints embody local properties of simple polygons and the nature of the relationship between noise and the features in the image. By minimizing these constraints we are able to deform ow initial model to fit the feature.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The extraction of geometric models that represent the features of interest in an image is one of the techniques of image analysis and understanding. By visualizing the geometric models of the features; one can gain a better understanding of the spatial extents, locations and separations of the features without the clutter of noise and irrelevant features. The difficulty in extracting geometry from images arises from the nature of the image data. Image data represents an estimate of a scene, since the imaging process may introduce artifacts that distort the scene. Simple closed objects may be mapped into features with holes or leaks (finite regions where the feature is indistinguishable from the background). Extracting just the edges of such a feature will result in an object with little resemblance to the original.

The goal in extracting geometry from images is to generate a topologically accurate representation of the initial object. Unfortunately, current methods either do not guarantee a topologically connected model, or they require techniques which may be more complicated than necessary. Traditional methods identify edges either through digital gradients [l] or through a minimization of edge type components 121 and then stitch the edges together to form a connected model (a difficult task at best). We propose a methodology that will extract a topologically closed geometric model from a 2D image. This is accomplished by starting with a simple model that is already topologically closed, and deforming the model based on aset of constraints, so that the model grows (shrinks) to fit the feature within the image while maintaining its closed and locally simple nature. The initial model is a non-selfintersecting polygon that is either embedded in the feature or surrounds the feature. There is a cost function associated with every vertex that quantifies its deformation, the properties of simple polygons, and the relationship between noise and feature. By minimizing these constraints an effect similar to a balloon inflating within a container or a piece of shrink wrap compressing around an object can be achieved.

div.head: Problem Space
div.p: The problem space that we are addressing consists of a feature that can be described by a single topologically simple polygon. This does imply that the feature itself is closed, but merely that the approximation (model) of the feature is closed. Figure 1 illustrates several features that could have been distorted by the imaging process and the geometric models that may represent them. Figure 1 (a) contains concavities which may be ignored. In this case, a polygon would "shrink wrap" around the feature. Figure 1 (b) contains concavities in the opposite nature as in 1 (a). The model in 1 (b) could be generated by expanding a model from within the feature (like a balloon). Figm 1 (c) is riddled with noise and leaks, but a model can still be generated by expanding a model from within the feature. Figure 1 (d) consists of a feature whose boundary is hardly defined, however, we can still generate a model of the feature by expanding the initial model from within the feature.

div.head: Results
div.p: There is a gain on @(a) of 10, a is allowed to fluctuate 15% from its original value, one neighbor to each side of the current model point is used to determine the local mean, and the inter-point distance is maintained within 20% of the local mean. Using a DECStation 3100, we are able to extract the models described in roughly 50 seconds. The ability to expand a model in real time will allow for the development of an interactive system where the user can pick the cavity and initial location of a model.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: An image can be visualized as an elevation map where the grey level indicates a measure of altitude. The boundaries of features will appear as peaks or rolling ridges of large area, whereas noise will appear as high peaks covering very little area. The image term we use simply reduces the height of all peaks (noise or boundary of feature) and sets the remainder of the image (region below the threshold) to some constant plateau (zero). The model then travels along the plateau until it hits a ridge on the elevation map. If the point tries to travel up the ridge it will slide back down to a position of lower potential. If a point encounters an element of noise it will move around the peak instead of trying to move over the peak. If the inter-point distance is smaller than the noise, the points encountering that noise will have to travel up the sides of the noise peak in order to satisfy the distance constraint. This will cause an increase in cost and may hinder that portion of the model from straddling the noise.

The form of edge determination used here (simple threshold) works well with scanned images, but if standard camera images are used then a more sophisticated edge detection algorithm should be employed. This will be necessary since the background illumination will vary through the image. Digital gradients [l], the Canny operator [7], or rolling ball algorithms [8, 91 should be used to define an edge or reduce the amount of background illumination.

The deformation functions we use provide a very fast method for expanding or contracting a model, but for best results requires that (zo, yo) be somewhat near the center of the feature. The dependence on the location of the focal point has been minimized by the local mean (neighbor mean) parameter. For the features that we have modeled, we place a circle with a radius of one pixel inside the feature and repel the points from its center or we use a circumscribing ellipse as the initial model and attract the vertex points to a p i n t within the feature. The circle is the best choice for the initial model if nothing is known about the basic shape of the feature. But if the feature was known to be long and skinny; then an ellipse could be used as the initial model, and the points in the model could be repelled (attracted) from the line connecting the foci of the ellipse.

By using the local mean for maintaining the distribution of points along the model; each point will behave in a fashion similar to its neighbors, rather than behaving like the average case in the model or like independent entities. This allows for points to reach the boundary of the feature without limiting the movement of the points still expanding. It also allows for points to keep expanding without effecting the points that have reached the boundary. Note that if only one neighbor to each side is used to calculate parameter p , the current point is kept equidistant from both its neighbors (within the percentage of p used to cal- culate dmin and dmaz). In fact the best results have been obtained from the features tested when only one neighbor to each side is used to calculate the local mean.

Since the distances between neighbors is allowed to fluctuate throughout the model, the points will dishibute themselves to accommodate the variations in the boundary as well as minimize the adverse effect of deforming the model relative to some non-central focal point. Portions of the model are allowed to reach the boundary of the feature far in advance of the remainder of the model, allowing distant gulleys to be reached. Since the distances between neighbors is allowed to fluctuate slightly without an additional cost added to the system, the model will stretch in order to pull its points off of noise and to conform to the variations in the boundary.

div.head: Characteristics of Constraint Based Model Extraction
div.p: Constraint based model extraction attempts to give the computer the same subjective contour extending abilities that are commonplace with the human eye. Our eye naturally extends broken contours across small voids to generate a virtually closed cavity so that we can better understand the extent and shape of the cavity. We actually say that we can see a fully connected boundary, or at least where the boundary would have been if it were there. However, getting a computer to perfm subjective contour extentions is not so simple. The methodology that Although the mechanism for expanding the model is constant throughout the deformation, different components of the cost function dominate during various phases of the deformation. Initially the deformation potential will dominate the cost function resulting in rapid changes in the dimensions of the model. When an element of "noise" is encountered, the portions of the cost function that maintain the distribution of points and the basic shape of the model tend to dominate. The deformation will decelerate in the region containing the noise until the model has worked its way around the "noise". at which time the expansion will accelerate back to its initial velocity. When the majority of the points in the model have reached the boundary of the feature, the model will fluctuate slightly. This is caused by the algorithm constantly fine tuning the model in an attempt to find the maximum fit. One term in the cost function will dominate the expansion until another term decides that it is doing more harm than good. When this happens, another term will dominate temporarily in order to compensate for damages rendered.

div.head: Minimization Technique
div.p: The software used to implement the minimization of the cost function was extracted from the cost-unulysis object [12] that was developed for The Clockworks [13], an animation and visualization system. The minimization technique uses an adaptive algorithm to move a point in the model in the direction of steepest descent along the cost surface. This direction is the gradient of the cost function Ci, and is estimated by numerically approximating the differentials % and 2. The amount that a point moves is adjusted based upon the past history of movements. The stepsize can be reduced if movement by the current stepsize results in an increase in the cost function; or the stepsize can be increased if the point takes numerous steps where the cost function decreases at every step. For the purposes of deforming a geometric model within an image, the stepsizes are maintained between [1/4, 21 pixels. This allows for rapid changes in the dimensions of the model when it is in a void as well as fine adjustments in the model when it encounters an element of noise or the boundary of the cavity. This is not a problem because we have set up the cost functions to introduce local minima whenever a critical point is found. A critical point occurs whenever a maintenance constraint (@(a), A(d)) is violated or when a possible feature pixel is encountered. The cost function is actually a summation of functions that calculate parameters from the current status of the model. The terms that maintain the shape and distribution of the model are zero until they determine that the current trend is violating the maintenance constraints. When this occurs, these portions of the cost function contribute a term that is linear with respect to the amount that the constraint is violated. This produces a local minima and a slope that will return the model to a state that is acceptable. Note that a maintenance constraint may be ignored if another term in the cost function is decreasing with a rate greater than the maintenance term is increasing. This allows for a priority to be assigned to the various constraints.

div.head: Future Work
div.p: This research will be extended to extract three-dimensional solids from slice or volume data. The principle will remain constant. A discrete model will be deformed to fit a feature through the minimization of a set of cost functions.

The initial model will most likely be some approximation to a sphere, similar to the circle used for 2D. The geometric model will be expanded in three dimensions allowing the model to wrap itself around any concavity in the feature. A simpler approach would be to extract a series of two-dimensional models from slice data and stitch the individual models together. The problem with this approach is that with the current two-dimensional algorithm, it will not allow for concavities in the direction normal to the slices. An example of such a cavity would be the inside of a wine bottle. If the bottle is standing, with slices taken perpendicular to the axis of symmetry; then the only way to get the model to wrap around the concavity in the bottom of the bottle is to expand it in 3D.

The parameters used to generate internal potentials, and hence control the shape and distribution of the model will have to be changed. If a straight transition is taken from 2D to 3D, the number of parameters that need to be controlled greatly increases. Despite having to develop new parameters for the three-dimensional case, the algorithm and methodology should extend without alterations. This should provide a fairly fast method for extracting a closed geometric model of an approximately closed threedimensional feature.

div.head: Summary and Conclusions
div.p: We have presented a method of extracting the geometric nature of approximately closed features through the minimization of a constraint based system. Each vertex in a discrete model has a constraint equation to minimize.

The basic principle is that a point in the model should behave in a fashion similar to its neighbors. The constraints model the local properties of deformation, images, and simple polygons. The deformation can be an expansion or contraction, various boundary event detectors can be inserted, and alternative models for simple polygons can be used. Once a geometric model of a feature is generated, it can be used for visualization or analysis. The concept of constraint based geometry extraction also extends very easily to three-dimensions. Our future research will focus on extracting solid models of features within volume data.

IV -Spatial Frequency and Topological Moderator The fourth class of constraint controls the local spatial bandwidth of the perimeter of the model. As an important side effect, this constraint also maintains the model as a locally topologically simple polygon. The two shortcomings of digital images that constraint based modeling addresses, sampling artifacts and noise, are handled by the spatial frequency and topological moderator. The feature of interest may have a partially defined boundary or be riddled with noise (as in figure l b and c). Under these conditions, the deformation of the model vertex may need to stop before it finds the boundary of the feature (in fact it may never reach a boundary if it is directed towards a hole). If a point's neighbors have reached feature pixels and the current model point has not, then this may indicate that the current model point is in a hole. If a point has reached a feature pixel and its neighbors have not, then this may indicate that the current model point is on an element of noise. This constraint will introduce a

This is done without ever determining explicitly what portions of the image are contour and what portions are breaks. By contracting a large model around a feature, the points on the model will approach the boundary of the feature. The points are connected by lines which may bridge small breaks in the contour. Note that in figure 7, the upper right boundary of the turbine blade has a concavity that the exnacted model bridges. The approach is based upon Witkin et al.'s work on energy constraints [lo] and Breen's work in generating goal-oriented motion [ll]. Here, the high-level motion of actors in a computer animation is produced by the definition and minimization of a cost function. The same idea is applied to constraint based model extraction by providing each point in the polygon with its own cost function to minimize. The cost function contains terms that reflect global conditions within the model as well as local conditions between various neighboring vertex points. These terms may be thought of as opposing potentials that either push the model towards the boundary or maintain various local constraints. The local nature of the constraints allows each vertex point to behave in a fashion similar to its neighbors while still allowing global variations in the model.
